articles.headline: ISIS’ Mysterious Leader Is Not Dead, New Video Shows
articles.snippet: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi appeared on video for the first time in five years, reasserting authority in the wake of lost territory and a major attack in Sri Lanka.
articles.abstract: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi appeared on video for the first time in five years, reasserting authority in the wake of lost territory and a major attack in Sri Lanka.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Five years ago, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi mounted the pulpit of a mosque in Iraq to declare himself the head of a rapidly expanding terrorist organization.

articles.headline: Labor Dept. Says Workers at a Gig Company Are Contractors
articles.snippet: The department exempted an unnamed operation from pay standards applied to employees, marking a shift from the Obama administration view.
articles.abstract: The department exempted an unnamed operation from pay standards applied to employees, marking a shift from the Obama administration view.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Labor Department weighed in Monday on a question whose answer could be worth billions of dollars to gig-economy companies, deciding that one company’s workers were contractors, not employees.

articles.headline: In California, Home to Many Hate Groups, Officials Struggle to Spot the Next Threat
articles.snippet: Lone actors who come out of the blue present a daunting challenge for law enforcement, even in a region where investigators have a solid grasp on extremist networks.
articles.abstract: Lone actors who come out of the blue present a daunting challenge for law enforcement, even in a region where investigators have a solid grasp on extremist networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: California has more organized hate groups than any other state — it has chapters for street-fighting skinheads and black nationalists, Holocaust deniers and Muslim haters.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Ali Winston

articles.headline: WeWork Files for I.P.O., Joining Wave of Cash-Burning Start-Ups in Going Public
articles.snippet: The company initially filed paperwork with the Securities and Exchange Commission in December, according to a memo to employees.
articles.abstract: The company initially filed paperwork with the Securities and Exchange Commission in December, according to a memo to employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over nine years, WeWork has grown from one work space in Manhattan into a global empire of trendily designed shared offices, business services and more.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Who Killed Atlanta’s Children?
articles.snippet: Forty years ago, a serial killer terrorized the city. Families have been searching for answers ever since.
articles.abstract: Forty years ago, a serial killer terrorized the city. Families have been searching for answers ever since.
articles.lead_paragraph: [For more coverage of race, sign up here to have our Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.]

articles.headline: As Buttigieg Builds His Campaign, Gay Donors Provide the Foundation
articles.snippet: In amassing a small fortune, the South Bend mayor has had the backing of an exuberant L.G.B.T. donor base. But relying on wealthy contributors carries political risk.
articles.abstract: In amassing a small fortune, the South Bend mayor has had the backing of an exuberant L.G.B.T. donor base. But relying on wealthy contributors carries political risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barely two months ago, when Pete Buttigieg, the mayor of South Bend, Ind., was rating no higher than 1 or 2 percent in national polls, he had a well-worn punch line he used as he pitched himself in living rooms and conference rooms where many of the guests were, like him, young, male and gay.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Shane Goldmacher
